alternatives.transcript: Welcome to this course on building systems using the chat GPU API. Previously, EZR and I have presented the course on how to prompt chat GPT. But the system requires much more than a single prompt or a single call to an Lm or large language model. In this short course, we'd like to share with you best practices for building a complex application using an LOM. We use the running example of building an end to end customer service assistant system that trains multiple calls to a language model. using different instructions depending on the output of the previous call and sometimes even looking things up from external sources. So for example, given a user input like Tell me about what TVs are for sale. We'd use the following steps to process this. First, you can evaluate the input to make sure it doesn't contain any problematic content. such as hateful speech. Next, the system will process the input. It will identify what type of query this is Is it complaint or product information request and so on? Once it has established that it is a product inquiry, it will retrieve the relevant information about TVs and use a language model to write a helpful response. Finally, you'll check the output to make sure it isn't problematic such as inaccurate or inappropriate answers. One theme you see throughout this course is that an application often needs multiple internal steps they're invisible to the end user. You often want to sequentially process the user input in multiple steps to get to the final output that is then shown to the user. And as you build complex systems using LOMs, over the long term, you often want to also keep on improving the system. So I'll also share with you what the process of developing an LM based application feels like and some best practices for evaluating and improving the system over time. We're grateful to many people that had contributed to this short course. On the open AI side, we're grateful to Andrew Condrich, Joe Palermo, Boris Power And Ted Sanders. And from the deeplearning dot AI team, thank you also to Jeff Ludwig, Eddie Shoe and Tommy Nelson. Through this short course, we hope you'll come away confident in your abilities to build a complex multistep application and also be set up to maintain and keep on improving it. Let's dive in. Yep.

So for example, given a user input like Tell me about what TVs are for sale.

such as hateful speech.
Next, the system will process the input.
It will identify what type of query this is Is it complaint or product information request and so on?

Finally, you'll check the output to make sure it isn't problematic such as inaccurate or inappropriate answers.
One theme you see throughout this course is that an application often needs multiple internal steps they're invisible to the end user.
You often want to sequentially process the user input in multiple steps to get to the final output that is then shown to the user.

So I'll also share with you what the process of developing an LM based application feels like and some best practices for evaluating and improving the system over time.
We're grateful to many people that had contributed to this short course.

And from the deeplearning dot AI team, thank you also to Jeff Ludwig, Eddie Shoe and Tommy Nelson.
Through this short course, we hope you'll come away confident in your abilities to build a complex multistep application and also be set up to maintain and keep on improving it.
Let's dive in.

summaries.summary: Short course on building systems using the chat GPU API. We use the running example of building an end to end customer service assistant system.
